instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients?
Output: Confocal Raman micro-spectroscopy was used in to acquire Raman spectra at different skin depths from the subjects' lower volar forearm location.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients were asymmetric least squares (AsLS) baseline correction and Savitzky–Golay spectral smoothing algorithm.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients?
Output: The VIP score metric was chosen to evaluate important chemical biomarkers in AD patients. It can go as far as allowing one to evaluate important chemical biomarkers that are differentiators between two study groups, indicating a reduction in ceramides in an impaired skin barrier function, a hallmark of AD.

instruction: What machine learning method was used in the past study that aimed to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients?
Output: The machine learning method used in the past study to evaluate the relevant skin chemical biomarkers in AD patients was partial least squares discriminant analysis.

instruction: How effective is the partial least squares discriminant analysis classification model in evaluating skin chemical biomarkers in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and developing an objective scoring method sensitive to skin barrier differences?
Output: The partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) classification model was found to be effective in evaluating skin chemical biomarkers in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and developing an objective scoring method sensitive to skin barrier differences. The past study mentioned that the PLS-DA model allowed for the classification between eczema patients and healthy controls with a sensitivity of 0.94 and a specificity of 0.85. This indicates that the model was able to accurately differentiate between the two subject groups based on the Raman spectra of their skin. Additionally, the variable importance in the projection score from the PLS-DA model helped elucidate the role of important stratum corneum proteins and lipids in distinguishing the two groups. Overall, the PLS-DA classification model proved to be effective in evaluating skin chemical biomarkers and developing an objective scoring method for AD patients.
